intro: Phlox cuspidata var. typica, commonly known as the narrow-leaf phlox, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the eastern United States. It features upright stems that bear clusters of fragrant, pink to lavender-colored flowers in late spring to early summer. The leaves are narrow, linear, and often have a pointed tip, giving the plant its specific epithet "cuspidata." It thrives in full sun to partial shade and prefers well-drained, moist soils. This species is valued in gardens for its ornamental value and ability to attract pollinators.
